body.p:
To His Excellency Beriah Magoffin
Governor of Kentucky

The undersigned Petitioners will respectfully represent that at the January Term 1858 of the Jefferson Circuit Court Adam Schweitzer was tried on an Indictment charging him with having committed a Felony & he was found Guilty & sentenced to five years Imprisonment in the Kentucky Penitentiary. Your Petitioners will state the facts as detailed to them upon which the prosecution was Instituted. Adam Schweitzer and one Joseph DeMarsh who was Jointly Indicted with him but who was never arrested made a trip on a coal boat to New Orleans and returned on a Steamer, leaving New Orleans together; on the trip up a watch was stolen from one of the passengers and the Testimony on the trial of accused showed that a man answering the description of DeMarsh was seen in the state room of the Passenger who lost the watch. DeMarsh left the boat before she arrived at Louisville & accused as we presume because he was the travelling companion of DeMarsh was arrested & altho no watch or stolen property of any description was found upon him he was tried & found guilty as above stated. He has now been confined over two years in the Penitentiary at hard labor and we believe under the circumstances he should be discharged, he is a man who before the above charge was made against him labored for the support of himself & his aged father & mother who have been mainly dependent
on him, and he has always before sustained a good character, never haveing before been charged with crime, He is a German, Ignorant of our laws, poor & was consequently not able to make such a defense as might have been made in his case. We believe that his punishment has been sufficient to produce the proper Effect, If it be admitted that he was Guilty; which we cannot believe and for the sake of his aged parents and that their old age may no longer be Embittered by the recollection of the unhappy condition of their son. We respectfully ask your Excellency to Pardon the said Adam Schweitzer & we as in duty bound will &c

J. M Vaughan
J. B. Ehuchs
N. L. McClelland
F. B. Jones
Geo W Doaner
H C Russell
D Forsyth
P. M. Moore
J C Baird

If the above facts are true and from the character of the gentlemen who have signed the above Petition they are I join in this petition

To His Excellency
The Govenor of Kentucky

Captain Sweitzer who hands me the above petition, I have known well since the Mexican War. I was not aware until now that Adam Sweitzer the young man to whom the petition refers was in any way related to him. DeMarsh escaped in Straw Bail and has now been taken and I am inclined to believe that young Sweitzer may have been ^led^ into the difficulty by the one who was man , seen under the hope, that the punishment which Sweitzer has received, may cause him to turn away from such associates and Acts, if Violation of Law. the watch was of little value. it is true but the case was made out by the Witnesses Yet the Young man was not defended by any Counsel. believing that He has suffered a great deal I join in the petition

E S Craig Atto
For Comwth 7th Justice
